title: Female cadet found hanged at Sandhurst ‘thought she was going to be discharged’
text:
Olivia Perks was found dead in her room at Sandhurst in February (Picture: Tim Graham/Getty Images)

An Army cadet found hanged at Sandhurst thought she was about to be discharged, a coroner was told.

Olivia Perks’ body was found in her room at the prestigious Royal Military Academy on February 6.

During a pre-inquest review hearing it emerged she was worried after being given a minor disciplinary warning for failing to return to her barracks following a weekend party.

Michael Rawlinson QC, representing Ms Perks’ mother, said: ‘Olivia thought she was going to be discharged in the critical period between February 2 and February 6.’

He said the 21-year-old texted a friend to relay her concerns and urged the coroner to call the woman to give evidence at the full inquest next year.

Advertisement

Advertisement

The hearing was held to narrow down the scope of the inquest and witnesses to be called.

Senior Coroner Heidi Connor said the former would not include ‘why’ questions – adding that ‘culture, bullying, relationships and drinking’ would likely be inadmissible.

She said she would listen to submissions on ‘the real and immediate risks’ at the next review hearing in January.

Mr Rawlinson said: ‘The concerns of the family are the failure on February 2 – as perceived by the family – to provide any support to Olivia and the failure to understand that Olivia and alcohol did not mix.’

Ms Connor said: ‘Olivia’s family is present here today, I am sorry to meet you in the circumstances we have found ourselves in,” she said at the hearing in Reading, Berks.

‘You are the most important people in the room today and I hope I will not lose sight that there was a very important person at the heart of this and that was of course Olivia.’

Ms Perks joined the academy in May 2018 and was in the final term of a 44-week officer training course.

During a previous hearing a provisional cause of death was given as ‘asphyxia due to hanging’.
